etymologies: late 16th century (also in the general sense ‘fact of seeing wrongly’): from French parallaxe, from Greek parallaxis ‘a change’, from parallassein ‘to alternate’, based on allassein ‘to exchange’ (from allos ‘other’)

definitions: the effect whereby the position or direction of an object appears to differ when viewed from different positions, e.g. through the viewfinder and the lens of a camera

examples.text: what you see in the viewfinder won't be quite what you get in the photograph because of parallax error

shortDefinitions: effect whereby position or direction of object appears to differ when viewed from different positions

definitions: the angular amount of parallax in a particular case, especially that of a star viewed from different points in the earth's orbit

examples.text: he succeeded in measuring the parallax of the star 61 Cygni

shortDefinitions: angular amount of this in particular case
